plants.name: Wintersweet
plants.description: A deciduous shrub known for its fragrant, bright yellow flowers that bloom in the depths of winter, often before the leaves emerge. It adds a cheerful splash of color and scent to cold, gray days.
plants.location: Native to China, cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide, especially in East Asia and North America
plants.funFact: Wintersweet flowers open in late autumn and winter, attracting early-season pollinators despite the cold.

plants.name: Poinsettia (Euphorbia pulcherrima)
plants.description: A popular ornamental plant often associated with Christmas. The bright red bracts are commonly mistaken for flower petals and provide vibrant color in winter when many other plants are dormant.
plants.location: Native to Mexico and Central America; widely cultivated indoors and in warmer climates globally
plants.funFact: The poinsettia‚Äôs red 'petals' are actually modified leaves called bracts that change color in response to shorter daylight hours.

plants.name: Hellebore (Helleborus spp.)
plants.description: An evergreen perennial that produces delicate, nodding flowers in shades of white, pink, and purple, often blooming in December and January, enduring cold and snow.
plants.location: Native to Europe and Asia; popular in temperate gardens in the Northern Hemisphere
plants.funFact: Hellebores contain toxic compounds and were historically used as herbal remedies with caution due to their potency.

plants.name: Waratah (Telopea speciosissima)
plants.description: An iconic Australian native shrub with striking large red flower heads that bloom in late spring to early summer in Australia, corresponding to December-January in the Southern Hemisphere.
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia, particularly New South Wales
plants.funFact: Waratah flowers are made up of hundreds of tiny individual flowers clustered together, creating their impressive appearance.
